fields.headline: News in brief
fields.bodyText: Outline deal for £8bn investment in Libya Spain and Libya have reached an agreement that could mean Spanish firms investing up to £8.4bn in the African country. The deal, outlined between Spain's prime minister, José Luis Rodriguez Zapatero, and the Libyan leader, Muammar Gadafy, could see Spanish companies putting cash into the energy sector, defence and aeronautics as well as nearly £5bn in a project to develop Libya's infrastructure. Gadafy, once ostracised around the world as a terrorism sponsor, has been trying to build normal relations with Europe after renouncing terrorism and nuclear weapons. Last week he went to France. Associated Press in Madrid Tablet on eBay may have been smuggled from Iraq A 4,000-year-old clay tablet authorities suspect was smuggled from Iraq was withdrawn from eBay minutes before the close of the online auction, Swiss officials said yesterday. Criminal proceedings have begun against the seller, a resident of Zurich, who faces a fine of up to 500,000 Swiss francs (£215,000) or a jail sentence. A German archaeologist who spotted the tablet, which bears cuneiform script, on eBay's Swiss website alerted German authorities, who tipped off Swiss officials. Iraq's national library and national museum lost many objects to looting after the US-led invasion. Associated Press in Geneva
